headerAndNotice.title: Information Processing Systems - Open Systems Interconnection - Basic Reference Model. Part 2: Security Architecture.
headerAndNotice.paragraph: *This analysis refers to key concepts of the ISO 7498-2 standard, part of the 7498 family on security architecture for open systems. Part 2 has an approximate cost of 150 USD on the official ISO website. We do not hold copyright for its full distribution, but we can legitimately present fragments and explanations based on its content, as it has been legally acquired for study and analysis. Additionally, you can consult the first part of the 7498 family for free at ISO 7498, which offers definitions and relevant foundations for understanding the security framework addressed in this section.

keyQuestions.title: It is normal to have questions.
keyQuestions.conclusion: To answer these questions, we must first define what system we want to protect. It can be almost anything: a house, a car, a building, or an information system.

deepQuestions.title: 1. What do I want to protect?
deepQuestions.body: The fundamental components of my system. If any of them fail or are lost, the system stops functioning. Commonly referred to as assets.
deepQuestions.note: * There is a security area responsible for classifying asset hierarchy: Risk Management.

deepQuestions.title: 2. What weaknesses does my system have?
deepQuestions.body: The system may have inherent weaknesses in each asset. These weaknesses are known as vulnerabilities.
deepQuestions.note: * There is a security area focused on vulnerability discovery called Pentesting.

deepQuestions.title: 3. What do I want to protect it from?
deepQuestions.body: From any event or circumstance that has the potential to cause loss or damage to my assets. We call this a threat.
deepQuestions.note: * There is a security area dedicated to threat analysis: Risk Management.

deepQuestions.title: 4. How do I protect it?
deepQuestions.body: There are different security properties I can guarantee absolutely. These are better known as security services.
deepQuestions.note: * This standard covers which services can be guaranteed and how to achieve them.

deepQuestions.title: 5. What if I fail to protect?
deepQuestions.body: An attack is a functionality that, by exploiting a specific vulnerability, materializes a threat.
deepQuestions.note: * There is a security area focused on handling attacks: Incident Response.

deepQuestions.title: 6. Can the probability of an attack be calculated?
deepQuestions.body: Yes, risk is the probability of occurrence multiplied by the impact it would have on my system.
